questions.question: 1084In patients with COPD, the emphysematous damage is most likely to involve which of thefollowing structures?
questions.explanation: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) usually have centriacinaremphysema which involves respiratory bronchioles.Emphysema is classified into four major types:• Centriacinar• Panacinar• Paraseptal• Irregular1096

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, andwheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not asmoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of thefollowing is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
questions.explanation: The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entireacinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema. It is caused due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of therespiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. It occurs commonly in the lower zones and inthe anterior margins of the lung and is most severe at the bases.The image below shows panacinar emphysema.

questions.question: A 25-year-old man is being evaluated for dyspnea and cough for 2 months. He is not asmoker. Workup revealed emphysematous changes at lung bases. He reports that his fatherand uncles were diagnosed with liver failure and lung disease at relatively young ages. Where1085is the gene encoding the defective protein located?
questions.explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of α1-antitrypsin deficiency. The α1-antitrypsin is encoded by theproteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14.α1-AT is a polymorphic gene located on chromosome 14. It is part of a larger family of structurallyunique serine protease inhibitors, referred to as serpins. The most common clinically significantmutation in α1-antitrypsin deficiency is PiZZ.α1-antitrypsin, normally present in serum, tissue fluids, and macrophages is a major inhibitor ofproteases (particularly elastase) secreted by neutrophils during inflammation. The absence of α1-antitrypsin activity results in excessive digestion of elastic tissue by elastase.Patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency have a markedly increased tendency to develop panacinaremphysema.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man was brought to the ED with fever, cough with expectoration, and difficulty in breathing for 1 day. He is a chronic smoker and he has had similar progressive symptoms for the last 4 years. Past PFT findings showed reduced FEV1 and increased RV with normal diffusion capacity. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario gives a picture of acute exacerbation of COPD. The most common bacterial cause of acute COPD exacerbation is Haemophilus influenzae. Moraxella is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, andchest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopyreveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot-Leyden crystals (arrowsin below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsivenessto a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reactionto environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma areless clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:• Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma• IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma orallergic disease• IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthmaThe sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:•Charcot-Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts orbronchioles•1099• Creola bodies desquamated epithelial cells-• Numerous eosinophilsNote: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma andother hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.question: A resected specimen of a lung is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?1087
questions.explanation: The image above shows markedly distended bronchi involving the middle and lower lobe of thelung which is seen in bronchiectasis.Bronchiectasis is a suppurative lung disease with abnormal and irreversible dilatation of thebronchi. It is an end-stage condition of various diseases that result in destruction of the bronchialwall and its surrounding supporting tissues.The normal clearing mechanisms are impaired, either due to congenital causes or due to bronchialobstruction. This results in pooling of secretions, secondary infection, and inflammation, oftenwith necrosis, fibrosis, and eventually cystic dilation of airways up to four times the normal size.Note: Kartagener syndrome is a primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad ofsitus inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

questions.question: Transbronchial biopsy from a patient showed the following microscopic finding. What is thelikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The image above shows alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies). This ischaracteristically seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP).Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts,alveoli, and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis.1100The clinical presentation of COP is the development of nonspecific systemic and respiratorysymptoms. It is associated with filling of the lung alveoli that is visible on a chest X-ray as patchyunilateral or bilateral consolidation.COP was previously known as bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

questions.question: What is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world?
questions.explanation: Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world.Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica (e.g., quartz). Individuals involved with theconcrete work, sandblasting, stone carvers, and jewelers using chalk molds are at high risk.Pneumoconioses encompass a group of chronic fibrosing diseases of the lung resulting fromexposure to organic and inorganic particulates, most commonly mineral dust.

questions.question: What is the most common manifestation of asbestosis?
questions.explanation: Pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen, often containing calcium. They develop most frequently on the parietal pleura and over the domes of the diaphragm. They do not contain asbestos bodies, and only rarely occur in persons without prior asbestos exposure. Asbestos occurs in two distinct forms: serpentine chrysotile (more common) and amphibole (more pathogenic). Exposure may result in the following conditions: • Localized fibrous plaques or, rarely, diffuse pleural fibrosis • Pleural effusions • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis) • Lung carcinoma • Mesotheliomas • Extrapulmonary neoplasms, including laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas. The image below shows fibrous pleural plaques seen on the diaphragmatic pleural surface in asbestosis.

questions.question: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsywas done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is:1089
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing typical asbestos bodies are suggestive of asbestosis.Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causingcapabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, andsolubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.Asbestos bodies are a typical finding. They are golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with atranslucent center. They consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceousmaterial and arise when these fibers are phagocytosed by macrophages.1102Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and arecalled ferruginous bodies.

These patients are at risk of developing both lung1103carcinoma and mesothelioma.Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multipleasbestos bodies.Option A: Centrilobular emphysema may develop in simple coal workers' pneumoconiosis.Option B: Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis is seen in silicosis.Option C: Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic andchemical dust (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde,penicillin products).

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of low-grade fever, dry cough, and progressivedyspnea. Examination reveals the following painless skin lesion. Chest X-ray shows bilateralhilar lymphadenopathy. Lung biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of thefollowing is not a feature of this condition?1091

options.D: Anergy to common skin test antigens

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing the lesion of lupus pernio point towardssarcoidosis. It is a multisystemic disease characterized by polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia.Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceousplaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks,telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilatingas lupus vulgaris.Immunological abnormalities include:• Polyclonal hyperglobulinemia•• A CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5• T-cell expansion and macrophage activation• Impaired dendritic cell function• Anergy to common skin tests.The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:1104• B/L hilar lymphadenopathy.•Non-caseating granulomas• Lupus pernio•• Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)Syndromes associated with sarcoidosis are:• Mikulicz syndrome - sarcoidosis combined with uveoparotid involvement• Lofgren's syndrome - acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythemanodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathyThe image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma.The image below shows stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies that are found within giantcells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.0001105000The image below shows laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins known asSchaumann bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.1106

questions.question: What is the most common gene mutation associated with pulmonary hypertension?
questions.explanation: Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2) is the most common gene mutationin pulmonary hypertension. Inactivating mutations in this gene are found in 75% of the familialcases of pulmonary hypertension, and 25% of sporadic cases.The BMPR2 receptor is a cell surface protein belonging to the TGF-° receptor superfamily. It isinvolved in the regulation of growth, differentiation, and apoptosis of pulmonary arteryendothelial and smooth muscle cells.Due to the mutation, there is enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis of vascularendothelial and smooth muscle cells leading to pulmonary hypertension.

questions.question: A 57-year-old man presented with a persistent dry cough and progressive dyspnea. HRCTshowed a crazy-paving pattern. Microscopy of BAL aspirate is shown below. Antibodiesagainst which of the following are seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and microscopy showing alveoli filled with a dense, amorphous, protein-lipidgranular precipitate are suggestive of autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). It iscaused by circulating neutralizing antibodies specific for granulocyte-macrophagecolony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF).1107PAP is a condition characterized by the accumulation of surfactants in alveoli and terminalairways. It can be due to impaired clearance or abnormal production of surfactants.PAP can be of three forms:•Primary (most common): There is impaired GM-CSF-dependent surfactant clearance by thealveolar macrophages. It can be due to:• Autoantibodies against GM-CSF (acquired/idiopathic/autoimmune PAP)• Mutation in GM-CSF receptors (hereditary PAP)• Secondary: There is a reduction in the number or ability of alveolar macrophages that causesimpaired surfactant clearance. It can be due to:• Silicosis• Immunodeficiency disorders• Hematopoietic disorders and malignancies1108•Congenital: It affects neonates and children. There is abnormal surfactant production due tomutation in the genes coding for:• Surfactant protein B• Surfactant protein C• ATP binding cassette protein member 3

questions.question: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatiguability, and weight loss. He was diagnosedwith squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilarlymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigmentlikely to be?
questions.explanation: 1109The black-colored pigment in the hilar lymph node of the resected bronchoscopic specimen islikely to be an anthracotic pigment.The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles areengulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes.This accumulates and causes the blackening of the lung tissues or anthracosis.It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution withcarbon particles, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in thehuman body as a result of air pollution in urban areas. The aggregates of the carbon dust mayinduce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker'spneumoconiosis.The following image shows anthracosis with deposition of black carbon particles, within thecytoplasm of macrophages.Anthracotic pigmentation - PulmonaryanthracosisAnthracotic pigmentation - PulmonaryanthracosisBlack colored pigmentin lymph node1110Option B: Melanin is brown-black in color which occurs as a result of oxidation of tyrosine inmelanocytes, as shown in the following histopathology of a lymph node.Melanin pigmentMelaninpigmentOption C: Lipochrome or lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen as a yellow-brown pigment inhistopathological sections of the liver and heart of normal aging patients, patients with severemalnutrition, and cancer cachexia. It is derived through lipid peroxidation and indicates freeradical injury and lipid peroxidation. The following image shows a cardiac myocyte with fineyellow-brown lipofuscin granules in the perinuclear region.Lipochrome accumulation in cardiac myocyte1111Lipochrome accumulation in cardiac myocyteLipochromepigmentOption D: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived golden-yellow colored pigment seen in conditionsassociated with iron overload such as hemochromatosis. The following image shows extensiveintra-alveolar hemosiderin deposition following pulmonary hemorrhage.Hemosiderin pigment1112Hemosiderindeposits
